title: How long must a couple live together before they are considered common law or are impacted by community property rules in CALIF?
question: My ex wife and I legally separated in 2005. We have lived apart since that separation. in early 2013 we started living together again in California. I have a large tax debt on my name that was assessed in 2009 while we lived apart.
answers: There is no common law marriage in California. Community property is only created during a legal marriage -- living together without a valid marriage may not create community property.

California does not have common law marriage. Your Legal Separation Judgment has un-coupled your assets and debts from those of your "ex" wife. The tax debt that you incurred subsequent to that judgment (assuming that no part of it was for pre-Judgment taxes) is your sole and separate obligation. If that is the case, your tax debt can't be assessed against your "ex" wife. There is no time requirement because there is no common law marriage and you have a Legal Separation Judgment that exists forever (unless you re-marry each other).

The major issue concerns your "legal separation" in 2005. Was there a Petition for legal separation filed with the court? Was a judgment ever entered?
If not then you would still be married and you should really seek legal counsel concerning the tax issues.
Was there ever a marriage ceremony for the marriage before you separated in 2005? Were you even married then?
California does not recognize a common law marriage.

Dear Sir,

I order for the lawyers on this forum to attempt to answer your question, you need to state the following facts:

1. What do you mean by legally separated in 2005? was there a judgment of legal separation?
2. How did you file taxes in 2009? separate, single, married filing jointly
3. There is no recognized common law marriage in CA. However, your question does not state whether you got a divorce decree from a court of competent jurisdiction.
